title: Resume
text:
Things I’ve done: - Went to the moon - Eaten a fig - Done a cartwheel - Fallen on my butt - Learned how to read an analogue clock - Legally changed my name - Made a mighty fine smoked gouda - Lied only once on this list - Looked mighty fine in a leather jacket - Made several colossal social blunders - Slept in super super late on a school day - Eaten one too many marshmallows - Started a discord server
Everything here is absolutely true except for one thing, if you guess it correctly I will give you four (4) jellybeans of your choice (except no green ones)

title: yonatan-grossman.github.io
text: I’m a 3rd year undergraduate at UCSB currently pursuing a B.S. in Environmental Studies. In addition to the usual ES coursework I have also participated in field work with sea turtles and will continue my field studies journey next fall by studying the ecosystem of Chilean Patagonia for a semester.

title: Things I love to do outside of school
text:
Staying active
I’ve never really enjoyed going to the gym, but I do love to stay active. Over my 3 years at UCSB I have spent a lot of my time surfing, hiking, swimming, rock climbing, juggling, dancing, and, most recently, started learning parkour and jiu jitsu. I always enjoy learning a new physical skill and it’s been really cool learning how to move in new and different ways.
This also includes spending as much time in nature as possible, and outside of spending time by the ocean and in the mountains I have managed to visit five of the nine national parks in California with plans to visit at least two more before I graduate.


Working creatively
Although this past quarter I have been somewhat focused on my work since I’ve been swamped with classes, I’ve been lucky enough to spend a good chunk of my time on creative outlets. I’ve acted for and assistant directed for film, as well as acted and written for several theater productions. I’ve also collaborated with friends on scripts and always have a few writing projects in my back pockets. Since taking GIS classes earlier this year I have taken an interest in map-making, and been using map-making as a creative outlet for my passion for cartography and data science.


Cooking
Although I always thought I was a somewhat decent cook, living on my own and shopping for myself has really pushed me to learn more ways of feeding myself. No one tells you that one of the hardest part of growing up is having to decide what to eat 2-3 times a day for the rest of your life, but it really is. I’ve taken this opportunity, however, to improve my skill in the kitchen and branch out into new territories. Two years ago I had never really cooked meat of any kind by myself, and now I have several recipes in the back of my mind for most type of protein. It’s also given me an education in creativity, because sometime it’s 10pm, you need to make dinner, and all you have is three cans of beans and tomatoes and some spices. I’ve really enjoyed increasing my competency in the kitchen and now look forward to trying out new recipes whenever I can.

title: ArcGIS
text:
I started learning what GIS was how to use the software earlier this year, and have since taken two of the classes offered at UCSB with the intention to take two more next year. I’ve really enjoyed getting to toy with spatial data and have even used the skills I developed to work on my own projects.
For my final project in one of my classes I was placed in a group with 3 other people and we were supposed to come up with our own project and then collect data and try to figure it out. My group decided to try to address the feasibility of re-introducing grizzly bears to California.
We collected data from various online sources, uploaded them to arcGIS online, and then worked together to create this storymap.

title: ArcGIS
text:
I started learning what GIS was how to use the software earlier this year, and have since taken two of the classes offered at UCSB with the intention to take two more next year. I’ve really enjoyed getting to toy with spatial data and have even used the skills I developed to work on my own projects.
For my final project in one of my classes I was placed in a group with 3 other people and we were supposed to come up with our own project and then collect data and try to figure it out. My group decided to try to address the feasibility of re-introducing grizzly bears to California.
We collected data from various online sources, uploaded them to arcGIS online, and then worked together to create this storymap.

title: ArcGIS
text:
Outside class
I’ve really enjoyed learning about and using GIS software, and have used it in some of my own projects as well. I am currently working on a project on my own that compares the distribution of various religions in central and south Asia, specifically the Indian subcontinent. Although the project itself is incomplete, I still have a lot of the data downloaded and ready. This is a graph of the data I gathered from a 2011 Indian Census about religious population by region.

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.4     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(janitor)


Attaching package: 'janitor'

The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    chisq.test, fisher.test



religion <- read.csv("data/religion_data.csv") |> 
  clean_names() |> 
  select(where(~ any(!is.na(.x)))) #read in the data then clean it. Also removes columns with n/a values

religion <- religion[1:35, ] #only keeps the first 35 rows (since the rest were n/a values)

religion <- religion |> 
  select(-c("x_63", "x_67", "x_70", "x_73", "code", "total")) #getting rid of some extra columns not useful to this graoph
  
religion <-religion |> 
  rename(other =
           other_religions_and_persuasions_incl_unclassified_sect,
         "not stated" = religion_not_stated,
         State = area_name) |> #rename the longer column names to something easier/more accurate
  pivot_longer( cols = -State,
                names_to = "Religion",
                values_to = "Population") #pivot the data to long format so there's only three columns

top_religions <- c("hindu", "muslim", "christian", "sikh") #new variable of the 4 most populous religions

religion <- religion |>
  mutate(
    Religion = fct_other(Religion,
                         keep = top_religions,
                         other_level = "other")) |> #drops all religions that aren't in the top religions and puts them in an "other" catagory (this turns them into levels)
  group_by(State,
           Religion) |>     
  summarise(Population = sum(Population,
                             na.rm = TRUE),
            .groups = "drop") #sum the values of the dropped religions into an other level

religion$Religion <- factor(religion$Religion, levels=c('hindu', 'muslim', 'christian', 'sikh', 'other')) #defines levels to control the order the religions are displayed

ggplot(religion, #data
       aes(x = State, 
           y = Population,
           fill = Religion)) + #axis definition + allows the fill color to be chosed by the religion
  geom_bar(position = "fill", stat = "identity") + #make a stacked bar graph
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1, size = 7)) + #tilt the x-axis labels and makes them smaller so it's easier to read
  labs(title = "Religion in Indian States by Percent of Population",
       subtitle = "Yonatan Grossman",
       caption = "Data from:  http://censusindia.gov.in") + #adds title, subtitle, and caption
  ylab("Population Percent") + #edits the y-axis label
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#F4C430","#219909", "white","#003688","red")) #chooses colors (I tried to choose ones that were significant to the religions and also contrasted well)
